docs.lead_paragraph: The federal spending bill includes funding for Middle East military operations, raises political donation limits and provides funds to fight Ebola.

headline.main: From Contribution Limits to the Sage Grouse: What Is in the Spending Bill?
headline.print_headline: From Contribution Limits to the Sage Grouse

docs.abstract: Highlights of $1.1 trillion spending bill, which includes funding for Middle East military operations and funds to fight Ebola.

docs.lead_paragraph: Learning — or relearning — how to tell stories requires some skill. And consultants and researchers are lining up to teach it, often for a hefty fee.

headline.main: Storytelling Your Way to a Better Job or a Stronger Start-Up
headline.print_headline: Storytelling Your Way to a Better Job or a Stronger Start-Up

docs.abstract: Alina Tugend Shortcuts column explores why storytelling has emerged as one of the most powerful tools for businesses, particularly in attempts to improve advertising.
docs.snippet: Learning — or relearning — how to tell stories requires some skill. And consultants and researchers are lining up to teach it, often for a hefty fee.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate is expected to pass the $1.1 trillion package, but not without delays prompted by unhappy members of both parties.

headline.main: Senate Set to Approve $1.1 Trillion in Spending
headline.print_headline: Senate Set to Approve $1.1 Trillion in Spending

docs.abstract: Senate is expected to pass $1.1 trillion spending package, but not without delays prompted by unhappy members of both parties; Sen Harry Reid says legislation is not perfect, but much better than likely alternative--three-month extension of federal spending at current levels.
docs.snippet: The Senate is expected to pass the $1.1 trillion package, but not without delays prompted by unhappy members of both parties.

byline.original: By ASHLEY PARKER and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: The incoming Republican chairman of the House Budget committee says he's going to draft a fiscal blueprint to balance the budget in 10 years and call for transforming Medicare into a system that places future retirees in private health insurance plans — much like outgoing chairman Paul Ryan did.

headline.main: New House Budget Chairman to Follow Ryan Framework
headline.print_headline: New House Budget Chairman to Follow Ryan Framework

docs.snippet: The incoming Republican chairman of the House Budget committee says he's going to draft a fiscal blueprint to balance the budget in 10 years and call for transforming Medicare into a system that places future retirees in private health insurance...

headline.main: U.S. Health Care Lags Worldwide for Those Over 65

docs.abstract: The United States still has mortifying lapses and problems, despite spending more on health care than any country in the world, a new Commonwealth Fund report reveals.
docs.snippet: The United States still has mortifying lapses and problems, despite spending more on health care than any country in the world, a new Commonwealth Fund report reveals.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama on Friday urged the Senate to ratify a $1.1 trillion, House-passed spending bill that has roiled his Democratic Party, judging it an imperfect measure that stems from "the divided government that the American people voted for."

headline.main: Obama Urges Senate to Pass $1.1 T Spending Bill
headline.print_headline: Obama Urges Senate to Pass $1.1 T Spending Bill

docs.snippet: President Barack Obama on Friday urged the Senate to ratify a $1.1 trillion, House-passed spending bill that has roiled his Democratic Party, judging it an imperfect measure that stems from "the divided government that the American people voted for."

docs.lead_paragraph: The Chocolate King is finding it difficult to relinquish his throne.

headline.main: Ukraine’s Chocolate King President Finds Promise Tough to Keep
headline.print_headline: Ukraine’s Chocolate King President Finds Promise Tough to Keep

docs.lead_paragraph: Behavioral economics has given us amazing new policy options to solve local and international problems.
docs.abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column observes emergence of new kind of policy making in some areas of world based on idea that humans do not always make decisions in a rational or unbiased way; notes World Bank report detailing how insights of behavioral economics can be applied to global development and health; says that policies informed by behavioral economics are rooted in real human behavior, cheap yet effective and often superior to larger, more abstract policy favored by some governments.
docs.snippet: Behavioral economics has given us amazing new policy options to solve local and international problems.

docs.lead_paragraph: One in five American consumers have blemishes on their credit reports because of overdue medical bills.

headline.main: Federal Report Highlights the Effects of Medical Debts on Credit
headline.print_headline: Federal Report Highlights the Effects of Medical Debts on Credit

docs.abstract: Ann Carrns Your Money Adviser column cites Consumer Financial Protection Bureau report that finds one in five American consumers have marks against them on their credit reports due to unpaid medical bills; notes report follows bureau's previous findings that medical debt, which makes up more than half of collection items on credit reports, can unfairly harm credit scores.
docs.snippet: One in five American consumers have blemishes on their credit reports because of overdue medical bills.
